column2: CHAPTER IX
column3: CHAPTER nine

column2: On the last Saturday in April, the New York "Times" published an account of the strike complications which were delaying Alexander's New Jersey bridge, and stated that the engineer himself was in town and at his office on West Tenth Street.
column3: On the last Saturday in April, the New York "Times" published an account of the strike complications which were delaying Alexander's New Jersey bridge, and stated that the engineer himself was in town and at his office on West Tenth Street.

column2: His business often called him to New York, and he had kept an apartment there for years, subletting it when he went abroad for any length of time.
column3: His business often called him to New York, and he had kept an apartment there for years, subletting it when he went abroad for any length of time.

column2: Besides his sleeping-room and bath, there was a large room, formerly a painter's studio, which he used as a study and office.
column3: Besides his sleeping room and bath, there was a large room, formerly a painter's studio, which he used as a study and office.

column2: It was furnished with the cast-off possessions of his bachelor days and with odd things which he sheltered for friends of his who followed itinerant and more or less artistic callings.
column3: It was furnished with the cast off possessions of his bachelor days and with odd things which he sheltered for friends of his who followed itinerant and more or less artistic callings.

column2: Over the fireplace there was a large old-fashioned gilt mirror.
column3: Over the fireplace there was a large old-fashioned gilt mirror.

column2: Alexander's big work-table stood in front of one of the three windows, and above the couch hung the one picture in the room, a big canvas of charming color and spirit, a study of the Luxembourg Gardens in early spring, painted in his youth by a man who had since become a portrait-painter of international renown.
column3: Alexander's big work table stood in front of one of the three windows, and above the couch hung the one picture in the room, a big canvas of charming color and spirit, a study of the Luxembourg Gardens in early spring, painted in his youth by a man who had since become a portrait painter of international renown.

column2: When Alexander came back from dinner he put more wood on his fire, made himself comfortable, and settled down at his desk, where he began checking over estimate sheets.
column3: When Alexander came back from dinner he put more wood on his fire, made himself comfortable, and settled down at his desk, where he began checking over estimate sheets.

column2: It was after nine o'clock and he was lighting a second pipe, when he thought he heard a sound at his door. He started and listened, holding the burning match in his hand; again he heard the same sound, like a firm, light tap.
column3: It was after nine o'clock and he was lighting a second pipe, when he thought he heard a sound at his door. He started and listened, holding the burning match in his hand; again he heard the same sound, like a firm, light tap.

column2: He rose and crossed the room quickly.
column3: He rose and crossed the room quickly.

column2: He stood for a moment in awkward constraint, his pipe in his hand.
column3: He stood for a moment in awkward constraint, his pipe in his hand.

column2: Come in, he said to Hilda at last, and closed the door behind her.
column3: Come in, he said to Hilda at last, and closed the door behind her.

column2: He pointed to a chair by the fire and went back to his worktable.
column3: He pointed to a chair by the fire and went back to his worktable.

column2: Won't you sit down?
column3: Won't you sit down?

column2: He was standing behind the table, turning over a pile of blueprints nervously.
column3: He was standing behind the table, turning over a pile of blueprints nervously.

column2: The yellow light from the student's lamp fell on his hands and the purple sleeves of his velvet smoking-jacket, but his flushed face and big, hard head were in the shadow.
column3: The yellow light from the student's lamp fell on his hands and the purple sleeves of his velvet smoking jacket, but his flushed face and big, hard head were in the shadow.

column2: There was something about him that made Hilda wish herself at her hotel again, in the street below, anywhere but where she was.
column3: There was something about him that made Hilda wish herself at her hotel again, in the street below, anywhere but where she was.

column2: Of course I know, Bartley, she said at last, "that after this you won't owe me the least consideration.
column3: Of course I know, Bartley, she said at last, "that after this you won't owe me the least consideration.

column2: But we sail on Tuesday.
column3: But we sail on Tuesday.

column2: I saw that interview in the paper yesterday, telling where you were, and I thought I had to see you.
column3: I saw that interview in the paper yesterday, telling where you were, and I thought I had to see you.

column2: That's all.
column3: That's all.

column2: Good-night; I'm going now." She turned and her hand closed on the door-knob.
column3: Good night; I'm going now." She turned and her hand closed on the door knob.

column2: Alexander hurried toward her and took her gently by the arm.
column3: Alexander hurried toward her and took her gently by the arm.

column2: Sit down, Hilda; you're wet through.	Sit down, Hilda; you're wet through.
Let me take off your coat--and your boots; they're oozing water." He knelt down and began to unlace her shoes, while Hilda shrank into the chair.
column3: Let me take off your coat-and your boots; they're oozing water." He knelt down and began to unlace her shoes, while Hilda shrank into the chair.

column2: Here, put your feet on this stool. You don't mean to say you walked down--and without overshoes!
column3: Here, put your feet on this stool. You don't mean to say you walked down-and without overshoes!

column2: Hilda hid her face in her hands.
column3: Hilda hid her face in her hands.

column2: I was afraid to take a cab.	I was afraid to take a cab.
Can't you see, Bartley, that I'm terribly frightened?
column3: Can't you see, Bartley, that I'm terribly frightened?

column2: I've been through this a hundred times to-day.
column3: I've been through this a hundred times to day.

column2: Don't be any more angry than you can help.
column3: Don't be any more angry than you can help.

column2: I was all right until I knew you were in town.
column3: I was all right until I knew you were in town.

column2: If you'd sent me a note, or telephoned me, or anything!
column3: If you'd sent me a note, or telephoned me, or anything!

column2: But you won't let me write to you, and I had to see you after that letter, that terrible letter you wrote me when you got home."
column3: But you won't let me write to you, and I had to see you after that letter, that terrible letter you wrote me when you got home."

column2: Is this the way you mean to answer it, Hilda? he asked unsteadily.
column3: Is this the way you mean to answer it, Hilda? he asked unsteadily.

column2: She was afraid to look up at him.
column3: She was afraid to look up at him.

column2: I came to tell you that I'm willing to do as you asked me.	I came to tell you that I'm willing to do as you asked me.
But it's no use talking about that now.
column3: But it's no use talking about that now.

column2: Give me my things, please." She put her hand out toward the fender.
column3: Give me my things, please." She put her hand out toward the fender.

column2: Alexander sat down on the arm of her chair.
column3: Alexander sat down on the arm of her chair.

column2: Did you think I had forgotten you were in town, Hilda?	Did you think I had forgotten you were in town, Hilda?
There is a letter for you there, in my desk drawer.
column3: There is a letter for you there, in my desk drawer.

column2: It was to have reached you on the steamer.
column3: It was to have reached you on the steamer.

column2: I told myself that if I were really thinking of you, and not of myself, a letter would be better than nothing.
column3: I told myself that if I were really thinking of you, and not of myself, a letter would be better than nothing.

column2: Marks on paper mean something to you." He paused.
column3: Marks on paper mean something to you." He paused.

column2: They never did to me.
column3: They never did to me.

column2: Hilda smiled up at him beautifully and put her hand on his sleeve.
column3: Hilda smiled up at him beautifully and put her hand on his sleeve.

column2: Did you write to me?
column3: Did you write to me?

column2: Then I wouldn't have come."
column3: Then I wouldn't have come."

column2: I didn't know it before, Hilda, on my honor I didn't, but I believe it was because, deep down in me somewhere, I was hoping I might drive you to do just this.	I didn't know it before, Hilda, on my honor I didn't, but I believe it was because, deep down in me somewhere, I was hoping I might drive you to do just this.
I've watched that door all day.
column3: I've watched that door all day.

column2: I've jumped up if the fire crackled.
column3: I've jumped up if the fire crackled.

column2: I think I have felt that you were coming." He bent his face over her hair.
column3: I think I have felt that you were coming." He bent his face over her hair.

column2: And I, she whispered,--"I felt that you were feeling that.
column3: And I, she whispered,--"I felt that you were feeling that.

column2: But when I came, I thought I had been mistaken."
column3: But when I came, I thought I had been mistaken."

column2: Alexander started up and began to walk up and down the room.
column3: Alexander started up and began to walk up and down the room.

column2: I've been up in Canada with my bridge, and I arranged not to come to New York until after you had gone.
column3: I've been up in Canada with my bridge, and I arranged not to come to New York until after you had gone.

column2: Then, when your manager added two more weeks, I was already committed." He dropped upon the stool in front of her and sat with his hands hanging between his knees.
column3: Then, when your manager added two more weeks, I was already committed." He dropped upon the stool in front of her and sat with his hands hanging between his knees.

column2: What am I to do, Hilda?
column3: What am I to do, Hilda?

column2: That's what I wanted to see you about, Bartley.	That's what I wanted to see you about, Bartley.
Only I'll do it more completely.
column3: Only I'll do it more completely.

column2: I'm going to marry."
column3: I'm going to marry."

column2: Who?
column3: Who?

column2: Oh, it doesn't matter much!	Oh, it doesn't matter much!
One of them.
column3: One of them.

column2: Only not Mac.
column3: Only not Mac.

column2: I'm too fond of him."
column3: I'm too fond of him."

column2: Alexander moved restlessly.
column3: Alexander moved restlessly.

column2: Are you joking, Hilda?
column3: Are you joking, Hilda?

column2: Indeed I'm not.
column3: Indeed I'm not.

column2: It's because they can't be at the mercy of the man they love any longer."
column3: It's because they can't be at the mercy of the man they love any longer."

column2: Alexander flushed angrily.
column3: Alexander flushed angrily.

column2: So it's better to be at the mercy of a man you don't love?
column3: So it's better to be at the mercy of a man you don't love?

column2: Under such circumstances, infinitely!
column3: Under such circumstances, infinitely!

column2: He got up and went over to the window, threw it open, and leaned out.
column3: He got up and went over to the window, threw it open, and leaned out.

column2: He heard Hilda moving about behind him.
column3: He heard Hilda moving about behind him.

column2: When he looked over his shoulder she was lacing her boots.
column3: When he looked over his shoulder she was lacing her boots.

column2: Hilda you'd better think a while longer before you do that.	Hilda you'd better think a while longer before you do that.
I don't know what I ought to say, but I don't believe you'd be happy; truly I don't.
column3: I don't know what I ought to say, but I don't believe you'd be happy; truly I don't.

column2: Aren't you trying to frighten me?"
column3: Aren't you trying to frighten me?"

column2: She tied the knot of the last lacing and put her boot-heel down firmly. "No; I'm telling you what I've made up my mind to do.
column3: She tied the knot of the last lacing and put her boot heel down firmly. "No; I'm telling you what I've made up my mind to do.

column2: I suppose I would better do it without telling you.
column3: I suppose I would better do it without telling you.

column2: But afterward I shan't have an opportunity to explain, for I shan't be seeing you again."
column3: But afterward I shan't have an opportunity to explain, for I shan't be seeing you again."

column2: Alexander started to speak, but caught himself.
column3: Alexander started to speak, but caught himself.

column2: When Hilda rose he sat down on the arm of her chair and drew her back into it.
column3: When Hilda rose he sat down on the arm of her chair and drew her back into it.

column2: Don't do anything like that rashly." His face grew troubled. "You wouldn't be happy.
column3: Don't do anything like that rashly." His face grew troubled. "You wouldn't be happy.

column2: You are not that kind of woman.
column3: You are not that kind of woman.

column2: You see, you are different, Hilda.	You see, you are different, Hilda.
She closed her eyes; her lips and eyelids trembled.
column3: She closed her eyes; her lips and eyelids trembled.

column2: Only one.
column3: Only one.

column2: And he threw it back at me a second time."
column3: And he threw it back at me a second time."

column2: She felt the strength leap in the arms that held her so lightly.
column3: She felt the strength leap in the arms that held her so lightly.

column2: Try him again, Hilda.	Try him again, Hilda.
Try him once again."
column3: Try him once again."

column2: She looked up into his eyes, and hid her face in her hands.
column3: She looked up into his eyes, and hid her face in her hands.
